title: Chapter 190

# Chapter 190

One and a half years ago in Satisfy, Grid was still level 21. Fresh from becoming Pagma's Descendant. Broke. Desperate.

Rabbit had cornered Khan in his smithy, the Mero Company's shadow looming over Winston like a plague. The merchant's proposal was simple: an item production game. Winner keeps the smithy.

Khan was drunk. Always drunk back then. His hands shook too badly to grip a hammer. So he'd turned to Grid with bloodshot eyes and begged.

Grid had said yes. The promise of gold made the decision easy.

The contest against Euphemina should have been straightforward. Make an item. Best quality wins. But the Mero Company didn't play fair. They'd arrested Grid mid-forge and thrown him in a cell to rot.

He'd failed. Lost. Screamed at the stone walls about божественный curses and shit luck until his throat bled.

Then Euphemina had appeared like some kind of saint. Freed him. Helped him reclaim the Ideal Dagger, rescue Huroi, earn the title 'Apostle of Justice.'

She was his savior.

Grid hated that.

***

*I'm not pleased at all.*

The thought crawled through Grid's skull as he watched Euphemina approach across Winston's courtyard. Old memories clawed at him. Gratitude tasted like bile.

It wasn't personal. Euphemina hadn't wronged him. The problem was simpler.

*If I can't produce a unique rated orb... what will she do?*

Grid didn't know the Duplicator class had weaknesses. To him, Euphemina was a walking apocalypse, a spell-slinger who could copy anything and destroy everything. Stronger than him. That made her dangerous.

She wanted a unique rated orb. Minimum. In exchange for returning the Ideal Dagger.

*What if I fail? What if I make trash?*

His palms went slick. The image of Euphemina's magic bombardment turning him into paste played on loop behind his eyes.

*I can't survive that.*

"It's been a while."

Euphemina's voice was bright. Cheerful. She smiled at Grid like they were old friends, her eyes sparkling with something that looked like genuine pleasure.

*She watched the National Competition. Saw me win.*

Grid's jaw tightened. Euphemina thought he was competent. That made the stakes worse.

"I watched your great performance in the National Competition on TV. You were really cool."

She beamed up at him. Literally up, her head barely reaching his shoulder. One hundred fifty centimeters of deceptive cuteness wrapped in an innocent face that made grown men stupid.

The crowd proved it.

"Who's that girl?"

"Seriously adorable. I want to put her in my pocket."

"Damn Grid... He already has Yura and Jishuka, now there's this girl. I'm seriously envious."

"Beauties always follow the heroes. God Grid deserves to be king of the harem."

Grid felt nothing. Euphemina's appearance registered as 'small' and 'young' and his brain moved on. He preferred curves. Maturity. Irene's body. This girl looked like someone's kid sister.

The lack of attraction was a mercy. It kept his head clear.

"There are many eyes watching." Grid scanned the gawkers. "Let's talk after moving."

***

*That attitude is still present.*

Euphemina's cheeks puffed slightly as she followed Grid's party toward the castle. The last time they'd met, he'd been the same. Completely indifferent to her looks. She'd fluttered her eyelashes, angled her face just so, deployed every trick in the book.

Nothing. He'd looked through her like glass.

*Is he gay? Impotent?*

Then the National Competition happened. Yura. Jishuka. Scandals plastered across every news site.

Euphemina's pride throbbed like a fresh bruise.

*Are Yura and Jishuka better than me?*

***

Winston Castle's gates swung open before Grid arrived.

"Welcome!"

The soldiers snapped to attention, salutes crisp. Grid returned the gesture without breaking stride.

"You worked hard."

Natural. Easy. Like he'd been nobility his whole life instead of a debt-ridden part-timer who couldn't afford proper meals.

Euphemina's eyes widened. "You seem to have become a noble?"

The logic tracked. User levels were climbing across the board. Experts estimated at least fifteen rankers held baronies now. Euphemina wanted one herself. The tax benefits alone would be worth the effort.

*A legendary class really is incredible.*

Lauel's voice cut through her thoughts.

"He is a viscount. In addition, he is the husband of Lady Winston."

"...Huh?"

The world tilted.

*Viscount?*

Not baron. Viscount. The same rank as Zibal. As Chris. Masters of guilds with hundreds of members.

*And Lady Winston.*

Irene. Earl Steim's only heir. A marriage that should have shaken kingdoms, announced with trumpets and political intrigue.

Instead, silence. Secrecy. A user husband.

*It was Grid.*

Euphemina's mind raced. You didn't marry into nobility by accident. The relationship between Grid and Irene had to run deep. Months of careful courting. Strategic seduction.

*He played a completely different game from the rest of us.*

Like those dating sims. Visual novels where you picked the right dialogue options and won the perfect waifu.

*Amazing.*

Her gaze locked onto Grid's back. Lantern-bright. Reverent.

*The first legendary class person transcends common sense.*

Grid was the first user whose skills her Duplicator class couldn't copy. The first true anomaly. During the National Competition, commentators had mocked his control. Called him clumsy.

Euphemina knew better.

*There's no need for control when you can just roughly use your skills.*

His PvP matches proved it. Overwhelming stats turned poor technique into brutal efficiency.

*I'm proud to know him.*

Grid had no idea. He wasn't paying attention.

***

Winston Castle's smithy was exactly as Grid remembered. Stone walls. The familiar heat of the furnace bleeding into the air.

He lit the fire. Watched flames catch. Turned to Euphemina.

"Did you obtain all the materials needed to make the orb?"

His voice came out flat. Blunt. He didn't mean to sound rude. Social graces just... weren't his thing.

Euphemina's expression soured. Her lips pressed into a thin line.

"Of course. It took me a year to get the orb production method and then six months to obtain all the ingredients listed. My preparation is perfect."

*One year? Half a year?*

Grid's brain stuttered.

*Is she insane?*

A year and a half. For one item. The waste made his skin crawl. You could earn millions of gold in that time. Pay off debts. Buy a building.

Euphemina was a fool.

But Grid was wrong. Euphemina was normal.

She played Satisfy like everyone else in her bracket: with goals. Heavy users chased objectives no matter the cost. Light users quit when things got hard.

Level 283. Private ranker. Obviously a heavy user.

Investing eighteen months for the best orb in the game? Standard. That was how you played.

Past Grid would have understood. He'd found Pagma's Rare Book after months of grinding without complaint. But debt had rewired his priorities. Satisfy wasn't a game anymore. It was a job. The current Grid couldn't comprehend Euphemina's mindset.

*She truly is scary.*

Cold sweat prickled down his spine.

*I can't upset her.*

Breaking someone's year-and-a-half investment would justify murder. PK. A hunt that wouldn't end.

*It must be at least a unique rating.*

Grid's hands curled into fists.

*It has to be.*

He closed his eyes. Mouthed a silent prayer.

*God, Buddha, Goddess Rebecca, God Judar, God Dominion, please protect my experience.*

Grid wasn't religious. Didn't attend church, didn't bow to altars. But he didn't reject gods either. If begging helped, he'd beg.

*Please. Just this once.*

"Let's begin."

The words felt heavy. Grid met Euphemina's gaze.

Her hand extended. A scroll rested in her palm.

"I'm asking you, the legendary blacksmith."

The system chimed.

> **['Mumud's Orb Production Method' has been acquired.]**

*...Mumud?*

The name was awful. Grid's first thought was disappointment.

*Sounds like Dainsleif.*

He had no idea who Mumud was. Some NPC probably. Another dusty legend.

Then he opened the production method.

His breath caught.

> **[Mumud's Orb Production Method]**
>  
> **Learning Conditions:**
> Mastered the Blacksmith's Craftsmanship skill.
> **Or** have Dwarven Blacksmith's Craftsmanship skill level 5 or higher.
>  
> **Description:**
> An orb designed by the dwarven craftsman Milepeu, who taught Pagma before he became a legend. It was widely known as Mumud's Orb because Braham's disciple, Mumud, loved this orb all of his life.

*Mastered Blacksmith's Craftsmanship?*

The learning conditions were insane. Higher than anything Grid had ever seen. Albatino himself, the greatest blacksmith before Pagma's era, couldn't make this orb.

Which meant one thing.

*This orb... it's higher rank than Dainsleif.*

Free. Euphemina handed it to him for free. No payment. Just trust.

The year and a half she'd spent wasn't wasted. This was treasure.

Gratitude bloomed. Genuine. Unfamiliar.

"Euphemina."

"Huh?"

She startled. Grid had never called her by name before.

He looked at her. Really looked. Let the calm settle into his eyes.

"I will do my best."

***

Euphemina felt the shift. For the first time since they'd reunited, Grid focused on her. Not through her. Not past her.

*On* her.

His face changed. The perpetual anxiety smoothed out. Confidence replaced it. A craftsman staring at a challenge.

A completely different man.

She smiled. Bright. Relieved.

"Thank you."

Grid nodded. The notification appeared again.

> **['Mumud's Orb Production Method' has been acquired.]**

*Interesting.*

Heat bloomed in Grid's chest. This was rare. A chance to create something legendary. As a blacksmith, the hunger roared to life.

He cracked his knuckles. Turned to the furnace.

Time to work.
